threadTopic

Summary
I help to ensure that only one thread runs a particular activity (topic), even across multiple JVMs. To correctly ensure that only one JVM is running a given task, every JVM must check this table before starting a particular activity. Additionally, once a particular JVM is assigned ownership, it must 'touch' the pertinent topic at least once a minute, updating the lastTouched time. Without this touch, a long running task will eventually be deemed hung/dead, and another JVM will be allowed to become the new owner. This could result in multiple threads running the same task. To avoid this, break long running tasks into smaller database transactions, and ensure that the topic is 'touched' periodically.


Fields
Name Type Attributes Description
auditLogTitle  calculated
max length: 1000
allows all 		abstract
  		This is used a the title in auditLogs. This should NEVER be null.  
code  name
max length: 50
allows printable 		primary key
required
  		The unique key. In practice, this is often the (simple) name of the java class that is being run. The names generally do not matter, as long as they are consistent across all JVMs.  
domainSubtitle  calculated
max length: 1000
allows all 		abstract
  		The subtitle commonly used for rows in a list. This MAY be null, if there is not subtitle.  
domainTitle  calculated
max length: 1000
allows all 		abstract
  		The title commonly used for rows in a list or dropdown field. This should NEVER be null.  
hostAddress  name
max length: 50
allows printable 		  The host machine on which the current owner is running. This is only used for auditing; not for coordinating ownership.  
hostName  name
max length: 50
allows printable 		  The host machine on which the current owner is running. This is only used for auditing; not for coordinating ownership.  
lastEndLocalDate  date abstract
  		The last end date based on the user's local timezone.  
lastEndLocalTime  time abstract
  		The last end time of day based on the user's local timezone.  
lastEndLocalTs  timestamp abstract
  		The last end timestamp converted to the user's local timezone.  
lastEndLocalTsMessage  text100
max length: 100
allows printable 		abstract
  		The last end timestamp converted to the user's local timezone, and formatted as a string that includes the timezone code.  
lastEndUtcTs  timestamp   The last time the owner ENDED this task. This is only used for auditing; not for coordinating ownership.

  		The last start date based on the user's local timezone.  
lastStartLocalTime  time abstract
  		The last start time of day based on the user's local timezone.

  		The last start timestamp converted to the user's local timezone.

max length: 100
allows printable 		abstract
  		The last start timestamp converted to the user's local timezone, and formatted as a string that includes the timezone code.  
lastStartUtcTs  timestamp   The last time the owner ENDED this task. This is only used for auditing; not for coordinating ownership.  
lastTouchLocalDate  date abstract
  		The last touch date based on the user's local timezone.  
lastTouchLocalTime  time abstract
  		The last touch time of day based on the user's local timezone.  
lastTouchLocalTs  timestamp abstract
  		The last touch timestamp converted to the user's local timezone.  
lastTouchLocalTsMessage  text100
max length: 100
allows printable 		abstract
  		The last touch timestamp converted to the user's local timezone, and formatted as a string that includes the timezone code.  
lastTouchUtcTs  timestamp   The last time the owner TOUCHED this task. This is used to coordinate ownership. JVM may shutdown, get restarted, or simply hang completely. If the current owner has not touched the record in the last 10 minutes, then it is assumed that the owner has died and that someone else should be assigned as the owner.  
lockVersion  lockVersion required
audit disabled   		This is used to coordinate optimistic locking in the database. This is usually not displayed.  
ownerUid  uid
max length: 30
allows printable 		  The unique id of a particular JVM. This is typically generated as a random UID within the JVM rather than trying to rely on an externally generated value. It is understood that restarting a JVM will likely change the ownerUid even if it is the only JVM on that machine.
